metadata.title: Synergistic effects of micro-silica and nano-silica on strength and microstructure of mortar

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Synergistic effects of micro-silica and nano-silica on strength and microstructure of mortar
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.02.115 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

com (H.Y. Chen). 1 School of Civil and Transportation Engineering, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China. 2 Department of Civil Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China. 3 School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China.
L.G. Li a,⇑, Z.H. Huang a,1, J. Zhu a,1, A.K.H. Kwan b,2, H.Y. Chen a,3 aGuangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China b The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
h i g h l i g h t s
NS is more effective than MS in increasing the strength of mortar. At same strength, use of NS would lead to lower SP demand than MS. Addition of both MS and NS has synergistic effects on strength and microstructure. NS should be added together with MS for maximum performance.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
As shown in the figure below, it is found that each of MS and NS is more effective in the presence of the other, or in other words, they have significant synergistic effects on strength when used together.

a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 12 September 2016 Received in revised form 30 January 2017 Accepted 22 February 2017
Keywords: Micro-silica Microstructure Nano-silica Strength Synergistic effect
a b s t r a c t
Micro-silica (MS), of much finer size than cement, has been proven to be effective in improving the strength and durability of concrete. With the advent of nanotechnology, nano-silica (NS), of even finer size than MS, is now available for production of concrete, especially high-performance concrete (HPC). To investigate the combined effects of MS and NS on the strength and microstructure of mortar or the mortar portion of HPC, an experimental program was launched, in which mortar mixes with various water, MS and NS contents but a constant workability were produced for cube strength measurement and microstructure imaging. From the test results, it was found that even a very small NS content of only 1–2% has substantial positive effects on the cube strength and microstructure, but a very high superplasticizer demand. More importantly, the combined addition of MS and NS has significant synergistic effects on strength and microstructure. These results suggest that NS should not be added alone but should be added together with MS to exploit their synergistic effects for maximum performance.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
y1@163.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
During the past decades, more and more materials with cementitious and/or pozzolanic properties have been used as cement replacement in concrete production. Some of these materials are industrial wastes or by-products such as fly ash, slag and silica fume [1–3], some are manufactured materials such as metakaolin [4,5], and some are natural materials such as zeolite and volcanic tuff [6,7]. Among these materials, silica fume, which is also called micro-silica (MS) because of its fine particle size of generally smaller than 1 lm, is one of the most popular supplementary cementitious materials used in production of high-strength concrete (HSC) and high-performance concrete (HPC) [8–11]. Due to the filling effect of MS and the pozzolanic reaction of MS with Ca(OH)2 generated by cement hydration, the addition of MS can effectively improve the microstructure, mechanical properties and durability of the concrete produced [12,13].
More recently, the advent of nanotechnology has brought in various types of nano-materials, which may have good applications in civil engineering, especially concrete production, due to their four major effects: size effect, surface effect, quantum effect and interface effect [14–17]. These nano-materials have attracted great research interest. For instance, it has been found that nano-CaCO3 can accelerate cement hydration and improve strength of concrete [18,19]. Nano-Al2O3, nano-Fe2O3, nano-Fe3O4 and nano-clay have been demonstrated to have great effects on microstructure, workability, mechanical properties and durability of cementitious products [20–26]. And, nano-TiO2 has already been used in road pavement and cement-based facade finishing to remove air pollutants due to its photocatalytic effect [27,28]. Moreover, carbon nanotubes and nanofibers have also attracted great attention due to their reinforcing and self-sensing properties [29–31]. Among these nano-materials, nano-silica (NS), with a high purity of SiO2 and an ultrahigh fineness [32], has become one of the most popular research objects for further advancement of concrete technology [33–36].
NS is finer in size than MS and therefore has a greater specific surface area. Hence, the pozzolanic reactivity of NS should be even higher than that of MS. Being much finer in size than cement, both MS and NS should be effective in filling into the voids between cement grains to increase the packing density of the cementitious materials so as to improve the microstructure and performance of the paste, mortar and concrete produced. However, whilst MS may be used up to 10% or even 20% of the total cementitious materials, NS is suitable for use only up to at most 3% because of the expensive cost, great difficulty in mixing and high superplasticizer demand when a higher NS content is used. Due to the relatively small NS content, the filling effect of just adding NS directly to cement is quite limited. For this reason, the authors are of the view that the combined addition of MS and NS may be better than just adding MS or NS alone. By first adding MS, which is finer than cement, to fill into the voids between the cement grains and then adding NS, which is even finer, to fill into the voids between the MS, the packing density of the cementitious materials and the microstructure of the cementitious paste could be improved to beyond those possible with only MS or only NS added.
It is therefore anticipated that the combined addition of MS and NS might give certain synergistic effects on the performance of concrete, and thus could be a promising way to produce even better HPC than what we are producing today. In fact, some studies have already been conducted along this line. For instance, Jalal et al. [35] found that the blended addition of both MS and NS can further improve the compressive and splitting tensile strengths, water and capillary absorptions, resistivity and chloride penetration resistance. Nili and Ehsani [37] observed that the
simultaneous addition of 5% MS and 5% NS could provide the greatest beneficial effect on the strength development of cementitious paste and concrete. Shaikh et al. [38] studied the bond-slip behaviour of steel fiber and polypropylene fiber in high volume fly ash mortar containing MS, NS or (MS + NS), and revealed that the combined usage of 10% MS + 2% NS could increase the pull-out force to higher than those with only 10% MS added or only 2% NS added. Nevertheless, systemic and comprehensive research is still needed to fully exploit the synergistic effects of MS and NS.
However, due to their high specific surface areas and tendency to form agglomerates, there is the difficulty of dispersing the MS and NS particles when mixed with water. One effective dispersion method is to use colloidal NS instead of NS in dry powder form [39–41]. Another effective dispersion method is to add a superplasticizer (SP) [42,43]. These two dispersion methods are not exclusive and can be used together. Somehow, the SP dosage needed for a given workability cannot be theoretically predicted and up to now has to be determined by trials. While performing studies on the uses of MS and NS, different ways have been adopted to set the SP dosage. For instance, Senff et al. [44] fixed the SP dosage in all the paste and mortar samples tested and Yu et al. [45] maintained the SP dosage at 4.5% for producing ultra-high-performance concrete, whereas Jo et al. [46] adjusted the SP dosage for each mortar mix to ensure that no segregation would occur. In this regard, the authors are of the view that good workability should be achieved first to ensure proper mixing and compaction, especially when added with MS and NS, which would substantially decrease the workability [47,48]. It is suggested that the effects of MS and NS should be studied with the workability fixed by adjusting the SP dosage until the required workability is achieved.
In the study presented herein, in order to investigate the synergistic effects of MS and NS on strength and microstructure of mortar, a number of mortar mixes with various water, MS and NS contents were produced for workability and cube strength measurements and microstructure observation. For each mortar mix, the SP dosage was adjusted to achieve the required workability. Based on the experimental results so obtained, the advantages and disadvantages of adding MS alone, NS alone, and MS and NS together are evaluated, and the synergistic effects of MS and NS on strength and microstructure are studied.

sections.heading: 2.1. Selection of materials
sections.text:
The cementitious materials comprised of cement, MS and NS. An ordinary Portland cement (OPC) of strength class 52.5N, which had been tested to comply with BS 812: 1996, was used as the cement. A condensed silica fume imported from Europe and tested by the supplier to comply with ASTM C 1240-03 was used as the MS. A dry powder form nano-silica manufactured in China with particle size ranging from 5 to 20 nm (as can be seen from the transmission electron microscopy images presented in Fig. 1) and high purity of silica (>99.6%) was used as the NS. Regarding the fine aggregate, natural river sand with maximum size of 1.18 mm, moisture content of 0.21% and water absorption of 1.10% was used. The relative densities of the OPC, MS, NS and fine aggregate were measured as 3.11, 2.20, 1.94 and 2.58, respectively. On the other hand, the SP added was a polycarboxylate-based SP with a solid mass content of 20%. It was a commonly used SP in the construction industry for the production of HSC and HPC.
A laser diffraction particle size analyzer was used to measure the particle size distributions of the OPC and MS, while the mechanical sieving method was used to measure the particle size
distribution of the fine aggregate. The particle size distributions so obtained are plotted in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mix proportions
sections.text:
To investigate the effects of MS and NS on the strength and microstructure of mortar, an experimental program was launched, in which mortar mixes with different water to cementitious materials (W/CM) ratios, MS contents, NS contents and SP dosages were tested. The paste volume (solid volume of cementitious materials + liquid volume of water, expressed as a percentage of total volume) was fixed at 60%, while the W/CM ratio by mass was varied among 0.25, 0.30, 0.35 and 0.40. On the other hand, the MS content by mass of the total cementitious materials was varied between 0% and 10%, and the NS content by mass of the total cementitious materials was varied among 0%, 1% and 2%.
Details of the mortar mix proportions are presented in Table 1. Each mortar mix was assigned an identification code of X-Y-Z, in which X denotes the W/CM ratio, Y denotes the MS content (%) and Z denotes the NS content (%), as listed in the first columns of
Tables 1 and 2. Unlike the other mix parameters, the SP dosage (in terms of liquid mass of SP by mass of the cementitious materials) in each mortar mix was not fixed but was determined by trial mixing, during which the SP was added to the mortar mix in small increments until a flow spread of at least 200 mm was achieved (such workability should be good enough for proper mixing and compaction). Altogether, a total 24 mortar mixes have been produced for testing.

sections.heading: 2.3. Mini slump flow test
sections.text: The mini slump flow test for mortar, which may be regarded as a reduced scale version of the slump flow test for concrete, was used to measure the flow spread of the mortar samples. The version of slump cone adopted in this study was the same as that used by Okamura and Ouchi [49], with a base diameter of 100 mm, a top diameter of 70 mm and a height of 60 mm. During the test, the flow spread was determined as the average of two perpendicular diameters of the mortar patty formed. Details of the test can be found in a paper by Li and Kwan [50].

sections.heading: 2.4. Cube strength test
sections.text: After the mini slump flow test, 100 mm cubes were made by placing the mortar into a cube mould, inserting a poker vibrator into the mortar for compaction and covering the top surface of the mould with a plastic sheet. From each mortar mix, nine cubes were made. The cubes were then stored indoor at a temperature of 24 ± 2 C, demoulded at one day after casting and cured in limesaturated water at a temperature of 27 ± 2 C until the time of testing. The mortar cubes were tested at the ages of 7, 28 and 56 days for their cube compressive strengths. At each age, three cubes made from the same mortar mix were tested.

sections.heading: 2.5. Scanning electron microscope test
sections.text: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to study the microstructure of the mortar samples. After curing for 56 days, the mortar samples were cut into small pieces and soaked in ethanol for over 7 days so as to stop the chemical reactions of the cementitious materials. The small pieces were then dried and stored in a sealed container before the SEM imaging.

sections.heading: 3.1. SP dosage
sections.text:
During mixing, a mortar mix with a lower W/CM ratio and a higher MS and/or NS contents generally appeared to be drier and more cohesive. Consequently, the SP dosage needed for the mortar mix to achieve the required flow spread of at least 200 mm increased as the W/CM ratio decreased or the MS and NS contents increased. The SP dosages for the mortar mixes to attain the required flow spread, i.e. the SP demand, are listed in the second column of Table 2 and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Fig. 3.
From Table 2, it can be seen that as the W/CM ratio decreased from 0.40 to 0.25, the SP dosage increased from 0.3% to 2.2% by about 6.3 times when MS content = 0% and NS content = 0%, increased from 1.2% to 4.5% by about 2.8 times when MS content = 10% and NS content = 0%, and increased from 1.0% to 3.6% by 2.6 times when MS content = 0% and NS content = 1%. This is expected because a mortar mix with a lower W/CM ratio would generally require more SP to give the same workability. More importantly, the SP dosage increased substantially with the MS
and/or NS contents. For instance, at a W/CM ratio of 0.40, the SP dosage increased from 0.3% to 1.2% by about 3.0 times when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and increased from 0.3% to 1.0% by about 2.3 times when the NS content increased from 0% to 1%. At a W/CM ratio of 0.25, the SP dosage increased from 2.2% to 4.5% by about 1.0 times when the MS content increased from 0% to 10%, and increased from 2.2% to 3.6% by about 0.6 times when the NS content increased from 0% to 1%. Hence, the increase
in SP dosage with the MS and/or NS contents is proportionally smaller at a lower W/CM ratio.
The separate increases in SP demand due to the addition of MS and the addition of NS can be more clearly seen from the curves plotted in Fig. 3. Comparing the SP dosage-W/CM ratio curves for (10% MS + 0% NS), (0% MS + 1% NS) and (0% MS + 2% NS), it is obvious that the addition of only 2% NS would lead to a slightly higher SP demand than the addition of 10% MS and the addition of only 1%
NS would lead to a somewhat lower SP demand than the addition of 10% MS. Roughly, the addition of 1–2% NS would already lead to a SP demand similar to the addition of 10% MS. Hence, the main problem with the use of NS is the relatively high SP demand compared to the use of MS.

sections.heading: 3.2. Flow spread
sections.text: The flow spread results are tabulated in the third column of Table 1. These flow spread results fall within a narrow range of 211 to 266 mm because the SP was added in small increments until the mortar attained the required flow spread of at least 200 mm. While adding the SP in increments, sometimes the flow spread increased quite abruptly to significantly higher than 200 mm and that was why some of the flow spread results are as high as 250 to 266 mm. During the flow spread measurement, the opportunity was taken to record any signs of segregation, if observed. No signs of segregation were found in all the mortar samples tested. Hence, all the mortar samples tested have sufficient cohesiveness to avoid segregation. In fact, although not quantified, it was felt by finger touching during the mortar mixing that a mortar sample containing a higher MS content or a higher NS content was generally more cohesive.

sections.heading: 3.3. Cube compression strength
sections.text:
The 7-day, 28-day and 56-day cube compressive strength results (each the average of three cubes made from the same mortar and tested at the same time) are tabulated in the fourth, fifth and sixth columns of Table 2, and plotted against the W/CM ratio for different MS + NS contents in Figs. 4–6, respectively. From these results, it is evident that the 7-day, 28-day and 56-day cube strengths all increased as theW/CM ratio decreased. Such observed phenomenon is expected because the compressive strength is well known to be governed mainly by the W/CM ratio and generally higher at a lower W/CM ratio. Moreover, the cube strength increased gradually with the age. The increase in cube strength from 28 days to 56 days was of the order of 5% to 15%, being generally larger at a higher W/CM ratio and smaller at a lower W/CM ratio.
More importantly, it is noted from Figs. 4–6 that the strengthW/CM ratio curve of a mortar with 10% MS is generally higher than that of a mortar with 0% MS and that the strength-W/CM ratio curve of a mortar with a higher NS content is generally higher than that of a mortar with a lower NS content. The shifting of the 7-day, 28-day and 56-day strength curves upwards as the MS or NS con-
tent increases indicates that the addition of MS and/or NS is effective in increasing the 7-day, 28-day and 56-day strengths of the mortar produced. Such observed increases in strength may be attributed to the nucleation, pozzolanic and filling effects of the MS and NS added [51,52]. Nevertheless, it should be borne in mind that such beneficial effects of MS and NS on strength can be achieved only if the mortar mix has good enough workability to allow proper compaction during casting.
Another important observation is that in Figs. 4 and 5, the strength-W/CM ratio curve for 0% MS + 1% NS and the strengthW/CM ratio curve for 10% MS + 0% NS almost coincide with each other, indicating that regardless of the W/CM ratio, the addition of only 1% NS would produce almost the same increases in 7-day and 28-day strengths as the addition of 10% MS. However, from Fig. 6, it is also seen that at W/CM ratios of 0.25 and 0.30, the 56-day strength of a mortar containing 10% MS + 0% NS is higher than that containing 0% MS + 1% NS, revealing that at such low W/CM ratios, a mortar with more MS but less NS has a higher long-term strength. Overall, the addition of NS is more effective in increasing the 7-day and 28-day strengths, but less effective in increasing the long-term strength.
The strength results also display significant synergistic effects of the MS and NS, which will be studied in details in a later section.

sections.heading: 4. SP dosage-cube strength relation
sections.text:
Although the addition of 1% to 2% NS would already lead to a SP demand comparable to the addition of 10% MS, the addition of only 1% NS would produce almost the same increases in 7-day and 28- day strengths as the addition of 10% MS. Hence, despite the major problem of provoking a rather high SP demand, the use of NS is not as difficult as it first appears. For instance, comparing the use of 1% NS for increasing the strength with the use of 10% MS for achieving similar increase in strength, the use of 1% NS would actually lead to a lower SP demand, as can be seen from Table 2 by comparing the SP dosages of the mixes 0.25-0-1 and 0.25-10-0, which have almost the same 28-day strengths, and comparing the SP dosages of the mixes 0.30-0-1 and 0.30-10-0, which have similar 28-day strengths.
Hence, the SP demands of MS and NS should be evaluated relative to the respective increases in strength that can be achieved. For such evaluation, the SP dosages of the mortar mixes are plotted against the 7-day, 28-day and 56-day cube strengths for different MS + NS contents in Figs. 7, 8 and 9, respectively. Each curve in the figures is for one set of MS + NS contents. From each and every curve, it can be seen that at fixed MS + NS contents, as the strength

was increased by lowering the W/CM ratio, the required SP dosage also increased. From the relative positions of the curves, it is evident that as the MS and/or NS contents increase, the curves are shifted upwards, revealing that the addition of MS and/or NS would increase the SP demand at the same strength. It is also evident that the curve for 0% MS + 1% NS is always lower than that for 10%MS + 0% NS. This implies that at the same required strength, 1% NS has a lower SP demand than 10% MS.

sections.heading: 5. Synergistic effects of MS and NS
5.1. Synergistic effect of MS and NS on strength
sections.text:
To study the combined effects of MS and NS on strength, the percentage increases in 7-day, 28-day and 56-day strengths due to the additions of MS and/or NS are listed in Tables 3, 4 and 5, respectively.
In each of these tables, the second to fourth rows depict the percentage increases in strength due to the addition of 10% MS at 0% NS, addition of 10% MS at 1% NS and addition of 10% MS at 2% NS. These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios and with or without NS, adding 10% MS would significantly increase the 7-day, 28- day and 56-day strengths. For instance, at W/CM = 0.30, the addition of 10% MS would increase the 7-day strength by 5.1%, 11.0% and 17.6%, when the NS content is equal to 0%, 1% and 2%, respectively. Hence, the effectiveness of adding 10% MS in increasing the
strength is higher at a higher NS content. Likewise, the fifth to eighth rows depict the percentage increases in strength due to the addition of 1% NS at 0% MS, addition of 1% NS at 10% MS, addition of 2% NS at 0% MS and addition of 2% NS at 10% MS. These results reveal that at all W/CM ratios and with or without MS, adding 1% to 2% NS would significantly increase the 7-day, 28-day and 56-day strengths. For instance, at W/CM = 0.30, the addition of 1% NS would increase the 7-day strength by 5.8% and 11.8% when the
Percentage increase in 56-day strength due to addition of W/CM = 0.25 W/CM = 0.30 W/CM = 0.35 W/CM = 0.40
10% MS at 0% NS 13.4 11.9 7.8 10.2 10% MS at 1% NS 13.0 14.0 10.1 12.6 10% MS at 2% NS 14.2 11.8 11.1 14.1
1% NS at 0% MS 5.8 3.4 7.6 9.4 1% NS at 10% MS 5.4 5.4 10.0 11.8
2% NS at 0% MS 5.3 8.0 12.3 20.0 2% NS at 10% MS 6.1 7.9 15.8 24.3
10% MS + 1% NS 19.5 17.9 18.5 23.1 10% MS + 2% NS 20.3 20.7 24.8 36.9
MS content is equal to 0% and 10%, respectively. Hence, the effectiveness of adding 1% NS in increasing the strength is higher at a higher MS content. The same applies to the effectiveness of adding 2% NS in increase the strength.
From the above results, it is evident that the effectiveness of MS in increasing the strength is higher in the presence of NS and the effectiveness of NS in increasing the strength is higher in the presence of MS. Such higher effectiveness in the presence of the other form of silica implies that there is certain synergy between the MS and NS. This can be more clearly seen from the results depicted in the last two rows of the tables, where the percentage increases in strength due to the addition of 10% MS + 1% NS and the addition of 10% MS + 2% NS are presented. At W/CM = 0.30, the addition of 10% MS + 1% NS would increase the 7-day strength by 17.4%, which is larger than the sum of the 5.1% increase due to the addition of 10% MS alone and the 5.8% increase due to the addition of 1% NS alone. Likewise, at W/CM = 0.30, the addition of 10% MS + 2% NS would increase the 7-day strength by 25.0%, which is larger than the sum of the 5.1% increase due to the addition of 10% MS alone and the 6.3% increase due to the addition of 2% NS alone.
To quantitatively study the synergistic effect of MS and NS, the synergistic effect is defined as the extra percentage increase in strength due to the combined addition of MS and NS, which may
be evaluated as the percentage increase in strength due to the addition of both MS and NS minus the percentage increase in strength due to the addition of only MS minus the percentage increase in strength due to the addition of only NS. The synergistic effects so evaluated for 10% MS + 1% NS and 10% MS + 2% NS are listed in Tables 6 and 7, respectively. It is noted that apart from some irregularities due probably to experimental errors, there is an overall trend that the synergistic effect is generally larger at a higher W/CM ratio and smaller at an older age. It is also noted that the synergistic effect of 10% MS + 2% NS is larger than that of 10% MS + 1% NS.
The exact mechanism of the synergistic effect is yet to be further investigated. At this stage, it would appear that the following are the possible causes of the synergistic effect. Firstly, the NS is much finer and has a much larger specific surface area than the MS. For this reason, the pozzolanic reaction of the NS would take place first, giving rise to a relatively high 7-day strength, after then the pozzolanic reaction of the MS would take place, giving rise to a relatively high 28-day strength [52]. It is envisaged that the pozzolanic reaction of the NS would gradually slow down and become insignificant after the age of 28 days, thus causing the synergistic effect to decrease as the age increases. Secondly, by adding MS to fill into the voids between the cement grains and then adding NS
to fill into the voids between the MS particles, the volume of voids could be successively reduced to increase the packing density of the cementitious materials [53–55] to higher than possible with only MS added or only NS added. Thirdly, the successive filling effects of the MS and NS might have densified the microstructure of the hardened cementitious paste, as depicted below.

sections.heading: 5.2. Synergistic effect of MS and NS on microstructure
sections.text:
The SEM micrographs of the mortar samples at a W/CM ratio of 0.25 and an age of 56 days, with 0% MS + 0% NS added, with 10% MS + 0% NS added, with 0% MS + 2% NS added, and with 10% MS
+ 2% NS added are shown in Fig. 10(a)–(d), respectively. From Fig. 10(a), it can be seen that without MS and NS added, fairly large crystals were formed and the microstructure was rather loose with many large voids. With only MS or only NS added, as shown in Fig. 10(b) and (c), some large crystals were still formed but the crystal sizes were smaller and the microstructure was more compact with less voids. In contrast, with both MS and NS added, as shown in Fig. 10(d), much fewer large crystals were formed and the texture was more dense and compact. These observed changes in microstructure reveal that adding both MS and NS has the synergistic effect of densifying the microstructure of the hardened cementitious paste. Such synergistic densification effect should
lead to not only synergistic effect on strength but also synergistic effect on durability, which should be worthy of further studies.

sections.heading: 6. Discussions
sections.text:
One may ask how statistically significant the observed synergistic effects are. To answer this question, it is first necessary to find out how large the testing errors could be. In this experimental program, for each set of mix parameters, only one mortar mix was produced for testing and therefore full statistical analysis is not possible. However, based on previous experience, the testing errors of such trial mixing and cube strength tests by research students, as evaluated by repeating the trial mixing and cube strength tests, are generally less than 3%. Moreover, in this experimental program, the cube strength was determined by testing three cubes cast from the samemortar and taking the average strength of the three cubes as the strength result so as to minimize the testing error. Hence, it is quite certain that the strength results are accurate to within 3% errors. More importantly, the values presented in Tables 6 and 7 show that there is consistently a positive synergistic effect, albeit it does fluctuate due to inevitable within-batch and batch-tobatch variations of the mortar mixes. It may thus be said that the synergistic effect depicted in the tables could not have happened just coincidentally by chance.
Another question is whether the synergistic effect could vary with the type of NS used and the curing conditions. In this experimental program, the NS used was in dry powder form, which was rather difficult to disperse. In theory, NS in colloidal form would disperse more readily and thus should have a higher effectiveness, or perhaps also a higher synergistic effect when used together with MS. Of course, further research is needed to find out the synergistic effects of different types of NS. Regarding the possible effects of the curing conditions, in this experimental program, the mortar cubes were cured in lime-saturated water. The limewater would provide an unlimited supply of lime for the pozzolanic reactions and thus might have enhanced the effectiveness of both the MS and NS [56,57]. In normal curing conditions, the effectiveness of the MS and NS could be lower and their synergistic effect might be different. Again, further research is needed to study the synergistic effects under different curing conditions. Both these two issues are interesting and worthy research topics to pursue.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text:
A series of mortar mixes with varying W/CM ratios, MS contents, NS contents and SP dosages but more or less the same workability were made for flow spread measurement, cube strength measurement at ages of 7-day, 28-day and 56-day, and microstructure imaging by the mini slump cone test, cube strength test and SEM test. Based on the test results, the following conclusions are drawn:
(1) The addition of MS and NS would decrease the workability but the decrease in workability could be compensated by increasing the SP dosage. However, the SP demand of NS is even higher than that of MS. Basically, the addition of 1% to 2% NS would already lead to a SP demand comparable to the addition of 10% MS. (2) The addition of MS and NS would significantly increase the 7-day, 28-day and 56-day cube strengths. Relatively, the addition of NS is more effective in increasing the strength than the addition of MS. Basically, the addition of only 1% NS would produce almost the same increases in 7-day and 28-day strengths as the addition of 10% MS.
(3) For a given cube strength requirement, the addition of 1% NS would actually lead to a lower SP demand than the addition of 10% MS. Hence, the addition of NS is not as SP demanding as it first appears. (4) The effectiveness of MS in increasing the strength is higher in the presence of NS and the effectiveness of NS in increasing the strength is higher in the presence of MS. Such higher effectiveness in the presence of the other form of silica implies that there is certain synergy between the MS and NS. (5) The synergistic effect of MS and NS on strength has been quantitatively studied and it is found that there is an overall trend of larger synergistic effect at higher W/CM ratio and smaller synergistic effect at older age. Moreover, the synergistic effect is larger at higher NS content. (6) The synergistic effect of MS and NS on microstructure has been studied and it is found that the combined addition of MS and NS has the synergistic effect of densifying the microstructure of the hardened cementitious paste. (7) The combined addition of MS and NS is a promising way of producing higher performance high-performance concrete in the future.
